subject: Re: [junit] correct order of tests
msgSnippet: So said  Dave Astels  on  11/8/2002 ... certain ... Absolutely. ... work. ... run ... one? Absolutely. MonteCarloTestSuite. :) J. B. Rainsberger, President,
messageBody:
So said Dave Astels on 11/8/2002

>On Fri, 2002-11-08 at 09:41, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>> So said Dave Astels on 2002-11-07
>>
>> >On Thu, 2002-11-07 at 04:44, Wolfgang Egger wrote:
>> >
>> >> Unfortunatley the TestProcedures have to be performed in a
certain
>> >> order. By default this is not ensured by the JUnit-framwork.
>> >
>> >Nobody's asked yet.. but why do you need them in a specific order?
>>
>> I think that we were afraid to ask, Dave. :)
>>
>> This is why when people learn JUnit, they should learn how to put a
>> test suite together "by hand" first
>
>Hmm. feel the pain, then discover Aspirin.
>
>It's also handy to know for when you don't have reflection (e.g. using
>J2ME or a limited language (like C++)).

Absolutely.

>> and realize that the test runner
>> is actually just automating some of what would otherwise be their
work.
>> It's a little thing, but important.
>
>True. BUT, the danger is getting used to having control over test
>order. I think a randomizing test runner would be neat... it would
run
>the tests in a random order each time. it would uncover order
>dependencies pretty quickly I think. I don't recall noticing such a
>thing. Have I jsut not looked carefully enough? Or should I write
one?

Absolutely.

MonteCarloTestSuite. :)
